translation.en: And action!
It's huge.
It's mind-blowing. I have to remind myself they're not real.
translation.ko: 압도적이죠, 진짜가 아니라고 계속 되뇌어야 해요

translation.en: It's like a historical movie, actually, what we're doing here.
translation.ko: 꼭 사극 영화를 만드는 것 같다니까요

translation.en: This is... 90% of my filming experience, here. Like this...
To come over here to do a show set in Williamsburg...
translation.ko: 윌리엄스버그 장면을 찍으려고 여기 세트장에 와야 했어요

translation.en: To do it in Berlin, it's kind of a... You know, it plays with my head!
translation.ko: 베를린에서 윌리엄스버그 찍는 게 머릿속에서 떠나지 않아요

translation.en: A series in Yiddish, for me, also, personally...
I think it's a great thing.
Dealing with a language that no one understands,
translation.ko: 아무도 이해 못 하는 언어를 쓰고

translation.en: with customs and rituals no one understands,
translation.ko: 아무도 이해 못 하는 관습과 의식이 나오겠지만

translation.en: but the essence of what's happening - that's universally understood.
translation.ko: 이야기의 핵심은 누구나 이해할 수 있죠

translation.en: It's a very beautiful and unique story
that shows, kind of, like, both worlds.
I don't think it's a story
about the existence of God or something like that.
translation.ko: 신의 존재 같은 게 주제가 아니에요

translation.en: It's more about...
the right to have your voice.
And people like me never really had that opportunity.
translation.ko: 저 같은 사람들에겐 그런 기회가 전혀 없었어요

translation.en: We never saw ourselves reflected back
in the stories told in popular culture,
so didn't know how to create our own.
translation.ko: 우리 얘기를 만드는 법을 알 수도 없었죠

translation.en: I think this is the first show ever
to accurately portray the Hasidic community.
translation.ko: 하시드파 공동체를 정확히 묘사하는 것 같아요

translation.en: These are real people
and their experiences are very universal and very relatable.
translation.ko: 누구나 이해할 수 있고 공감 가능한 경험을 갖고 있죠

translation.en: When the community watches it,
and somebody like me watches it and sees...
that this girl lived exactly like she lives,
and she was able to muster the courage to follow her dreams...
translation.ko: 자기 꿈을 좇을 용기를 내는 걸 본다면

translation.en: Maybe this girl can, too.
When I met Anna and Alexa,
when I became friends with them,
I realized that if anybody is ever going to be able to really grasp
translation.ko: 이 사람들이라면 이 이야기를 진정으로 이해하고

translation.en: what this story is about, and execute it
in a way that is going to have a positive cultural impact, it's these women.
translation.ko: 바람직한 문화적 영향을 줄 수 있다고 생각했어요

translation.en: After I met Deborah, I read her book and I thought it was amazing.
translation.ko: 처음 만난 후 데버라의 책을 읽었는데, 굉장하더라고요

translation.en: I read it in one sitting and I couldn't put it down.
translation.ko: 책을 내려놓지도 못하고 한 번에 다 봤어요

translation.en: And then she said,
"Well, why don't you make my book into a TV show?"
translation.ko: '내 책을 원작으로 TV 드라마를 만들지 그래?'

translation.en: Anna and I wanted to make a show
in which we could work through
a lot of the topics we discuss a lot,
translation.ko: 우리가 자주 토론하는 주제를 투영한 것이었죠

translation.en: especially about being Jewish in Germany.
[Anna] This story is about a woman...
who is searching for herself,
and searching for her community in the world.
translation.ko: 세상에 나가 자기 공동체를 찾는 것이죠

translation.en: [Shira] Esther is a 19-year-old girl.
She was born and raised in Williamsburg, Brooklyn,
in the community
called Satmar.
Don't forget, Esty. He speaks first.
translation.ko: 잊지 마, 에스티 남자가 먼저 말하는 거야

translation.en: She grows up in a very religious neighborhood...
and frees herself from an unhappy arranged marriage
and flees to Berlin.
[Alexa] Her story is unique and romantic.
We just felt that it was so different that somebody who would leave
this very insular community in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, New York,
translation.ko: 뉴욕 브루클린 윌리엄스버그의 배타적인 공동체를 떠나

translation.en: and find their way here, out of choice...
translation.ko: 이곳에서 자기 길을 찾는 선택을 하다니

translation.en: From a very young age, she always felt very different,
translation.ko: 에스터는 어릴 때부터 자신이 남들과 다르다고 느꼈고

translation.en: had been told she's very different,
because of the fact that she always also has these questions within her
translation.ko: 그래서 에스터는 항상 이런저런 의문을 품었어요

translation.en: and she has that chutzpah, you can say.
[Alexa] The Satmar Jews are a Hasidic community
translation.ko: 사트마 유대인들은 하시드파 공동체 중 하나로

translation.en: originally from the town of Satmar, in Hungary.
They are mostly descendants of Holocaust survivors
and started by Holocaust survivors in New York, after the war.
translation.ko: 홀로코스트 생존자들이 전쟁 후 뉴욕에서 시작한 공동체죠

translation.en: This, kind of, makes them a little bit different
than a lot of other Hasidic communities,
because they really developed what they were about after the war,
and not before.
It is founded by people
who are struggling with the most immense trauma we can imagine.
And for the first generation, I would say, even for the first two generations,
translation.ko: 그리고 아마도 처음 한두 세대의 경우에

translation.en: this trauma was a driving force
behind the ideological structures of this community.
translation.ko: 이 공동체의 이념적 구조에 원동력이 됐을 거예요

translation.en: The Satmar community is also special, in that Yiddish is their native language,
translation.ko: 사트마 공동체의 모국어는 이디시어라는 점도 특별하죠

translation.en: and I think they can be credited to some degree
with keeping Yiddish alive.
But why Berlin?
-Think about it. -What?
Her mother lives in Berlin!
It was important to us
to make changes in the present day story
translation.ko: 현재 시점 이야기는 데버라 펠드먼의 실제 삶과

translation.en: from Deborah Feldman's real life,
because she is a young woman, she's a public figure,
she's a public intellectual,
and we wanted Esther's Berlin life to be very different
translation.ko: 우린 에스터의 베를린살이를 데버라의 베를린 경험과

translation.en: from real Deborah's Berlin life.
So, in a sense, the flashbacks are based on the book,
translation.ko: 그래서 과거 회상은 책을 바탕으로 만들었지만

translation.en: but the present day story is entirely made up.
translation.ko: 현재 이야기는 아예 새로 만들었다고 할 수 있죠

translation.en: You have to go beyond cliché,
beyond our projection on to what the life might be
translation.ko: 이런 공동체에서의 삶이 어떨지 우리가 상상하는 것

translation.en: in a community like this.
[Anna] It was very important to us to get not just the look and feel
and costumes and rituals and everything correct,
translation.ko: 의복, 의식을 정확하게 하는 것뿐만 아니라

translation.en: but to inhabit the ideas of these characters' worlds
in a way that felt authentic,
but heightened for television.
I just feel, like, when you're showing different communities
translation.ko: 제 생각엔 여러 가지 공동체를 보여줄 때

translation.en: and especially communities on the margins,
you want to get the details right.
We knew it was so important to get people onboard,
translation.ko: 당사자들이 참여하는 게 중요하다는 걸 알았죠

translation.en: not just as actors,
but behind and in front of the camera, who are from this community.
translation.ko: 이 공동체 출신인 사람들이 곳곳에 참여하는 게 중요했어요

translation.en: So, one of the first people we hired
translation.ko: 그래서 제일 초반에 섭외한 사람 중

translation.en: was Eli Rosen
who is an actor, translator
and, kind of, specialist when it comes to Yiddish.
translation.ko: 이디시어의 전문가라고 할 수 있는 사람이죠

translation.en: [Anna] Eli Rosen was, like, our guide, you know. He was our spirit guide.
translation.ko: 엘리 로젠은 저희의 길잡이였죠 정신적 길잡이랄까요

translation.en: He not only translated the scripts, he coached the actors in Yiddish,
translation.ko: 대본 번역뿐만이 아니라 배우들의 이디시어를 감독하고

translation.en: he helped us with all the cultural details and he played the rabbi.
translation.ko: 문화적 디테일 표현도 도와주고 랍비를 연기하기도 했어요

translation.en: When I was given the opportunity to help ensure
translation.ko: 제게 기회가 주어져서 작품이 진정한 대표성을 띠도록 도울 수 있게 됐을 때

translation.en: that it was representative and that it is authentic...
translation.ko: 작품이 진정한 대표성을 띠도록 도울 수 있게 됐을 때

translation.en: jumped at it.
Directing the scenes which are set within or in the ultra-orthodox world,
translation.ko: 굉장히 전통적인 세계에 들어가 그 속의 장면을 연출하면서

translation.en: I would have been lost without this advice.
translation.ko: 조언이 없었다면 전 헤매고 말았을 거예요

translation.en: We had two research trips to New York with our entire team,
translation.ko: 우리 팀 전체가 뉴욕 탐방 여행을 2번 갔어요

translation.en: not just to watch and look and touch everything we saw,
translation.ko: 보고 구경하고 이 모든 걸 만지는 것 외에도

translation.en: but we got access to meeting people who are still in this community.
translation.ko: 아직 공동체에 사는 사람들과 만날 수 있었죠

translation.en: We really tried to offer our heads of department as much access.
translation.ko: 우리 담당자들에게 최대한 접근권을 주려고 노력했어요

translation.en: These trips, of course, are, like, a hunt for impressions,
translation.ko: 물론 이런 탐방은 느낌을 찾아 떠나는 거죠

translation.en: for feeling atmosphere,
for just watching, just taking things in...
It was, kind of, image-based research.
We looked around, we took so many pictures,
and we tried to inhale this world
by the visual impressions we got.
[Justine] We were taken around New York
on a tour of Williamsburg by an ex-Satmar woman
translation.ko: 윌리엄스버그를 안내해준 분은 사트마에서 나온 여성으로

translation.en: who had grown up there.
She'd had her first child there and been married and everything,
translation.ko: 거기서 첫 아이도 낳고 결혼했다고 하더군요

translation.en: and she walked us through a lot of Williamsburg
and the traditions within the exterior buildings.
translation.ko: 겉으로 드러난 건물 안쪽의 전통을 소개해줬어요

translation.en: Silke was taking lots of notes for her world,
translation.ko: 질케는 작품의 세계를 만들려고 잔뜩 필기했고

translation.en: and I was taking notes
for the characters that I was going to be building.
We started shooting more of the past,
translation.ko: 저희는 과거 장면을 더 많이 찍기 시작했죠

translation.en: like, the Williamsburg parts,
and then we moved to Berlin,
so, suddenly, something also felt different.
Also, moving from Yiddish to English
translation.ko: 또 이디시어를 쓰다가 영어를 쓰는 점이나

translation.en: and different outfits and makeup, suddenly, and the hair...
There are so many different hairs.
The bald... there's this and there's the wig.
And there's... Esty has so many faces.
[Justine] I had spoken to Deborah Feldman before we started the project
translation.ko: 프로젝트를 시작하기 전 데버라 펠드먼과 대화했어요

translation.en: about her personal experience
of transitioning from Satmar modesty clothing
to Western clothing, I suppose you'd call it.
And she said it took her a long time and it was a slow process,
translation.ko: 데버라는 이걸 받아들이는 데 오랜 시간이 걸렸다고 했어요

translation.en: and she pushed herself to experience wearing T-shirts
and showing her arms and showing more flesh,
and she said it did take a long time, so I wanted to show that.
translation.ko: 오랜 시간이 걸렸다고 해서 전 이걸 나타내고 싶었죠

translation.en: I wanted to reflect Deborah's experience with Esther.
It was so hard to create, in a way,
translation.ko: 이 작품을 만들면서 아주 힘들었던 점은

translation.en: a production that is much like a period film,
but plays in the world of today.
To create the costumes for that was a very big challenge.
translation.ko: 그래서 의상을 제작하는 건 엄청난 도전이었죠

translation.en: Like the sets that played in two worlds,
we had costume that played in two worlds,
plus a character who has an arc
in not just her character, but also in her looks and in her clothes.
translation.ko: 캐릭터뿐만이 아니라 외모와 의상에서도 흐름을 갖죠

translation.en: Our production designer
knew which exterior locations we were going to be using there
translation.ko: 저희가 어떤 외부 촬영장을 이용할 것인지 알고

translation.en: and built made-to-measure sets here to sync with those exteriors.
translation.ko: 맞춤 세트장을 만들어서 외부 촬영장과 일치하게 했어요

translation.en: [Wolfgang] We have complicated locations
because we shot the New York part here in Berlin.
translation.ko: 뉴욕 장면의 대부분을 이곳 베를린에서 찍었거든요

translation.en: Why Germany?
With the other movies I did before, we came through the windows,
translation.ko: 제가 전에 한 다른 영화들은 창밖에서 촬영했다면

translation.en: and now, I do everything inside.
So maybe this is...
This is a very first experience, also, for me.
[Alexa] Wolfgang is an incredible cinematographer -
I mean, he has shot some of the most incredible documentaries.
translation.ko: 아주 대단한 다큐멘터리들도 촬영한 경력이 있고요

translation.en: He's able to work with natural light, work spontaneously,
translation.ko: 자연광 사용도 능숙하고 즉흥적인 작업도 잘하고

translation.en: he does a lot of...
We joked that he's "the handheld Steadicam."
He's good at combining different kinds of light.
translation.ko: 여러 종류의 조명을 잘 조합해서 써요

translation.en: Because we were matching set interiors with real exteriors,
translation.ko: 저희는 실내 세트장을 실제 실외 환경과 맞춰야 해서

translation.en: the lighting was very delicate,
and Wolfgang was incredible at that.
When I watch the material in post-production,
I think it's very difficult to see what's inside and what's outside,
what was New York and Berlin.
She's not here?
[Alexa] Shira Haas is a talent. What a face!
I mean, she needs to only move a part of her face
and it can make you cry or laugh.
Shira is just... an enormous, enormous actress.
So talented, so gifted, such a hard worker...
translation.ko: 정말 유능하고 재능이 넘치고 아주 성실해요

translation.en: And it was pure joy, every day... It was pure joy to work with Shira.
translation.ko: 시라와 일하는 하루하루가 행복 그 자체였어요

translation.en: I think that what's really beautiful in Esty
is that she really, really, really...
Even though she's been told that she's different,
translation.ko: 자신이 남들과 다르다는 말을 평생 들어왔고

translation.en: and feels she is different,
she always tries very, very hard to fit in, really,
translation.ko: 남들과 어울리려고 항상 최선을 다한다는 거예요

translation.en: and she really wants to find that feeling of belonging and happiness.
translation.ko: 그리고 소속감과 행복을 반드시 찾고 싶어 하죠

translation.en: [Anna] We have, sort of, four main characters.
I mean, Esther's the main character,
but the other main characters are all Satmar characters,
translation.ko: 다른 주요 인물들은 전부 사트마 출신인데

translation.en: dealing with being inside and outside at the same time.
[Alex] She was kicked out, or she left the community,
translation.ko: 제가 맡은 역은 15년 전에 공동체에서 쫓겨났거나

translation.en: about 15 years before.
It's obviously that role that attracted me, really,
to the whole thing.
[Anna] With Amit Rahav, we had never seen him acting in another project.
translation.ko: 아미트 라하브가 출연한 다른 작품을 본 적이 없었어요

translation.en: We just saw him in the audition. We were all blown away.
translation.ko: 오디션에서 처음 봤는데 아미트 역시 정말 굉장했죠

translation.en: And he just kills it in every scene.
He's a natural talent, you know.
I think that he's just
very naive and innocent,
because it's not weakness.
He has just, like, one truth, and this is the one truth he knows.
translation.ko: 알고 있는 진실이 단 하나일 뿐인 거죠

translation.en: It's around here somewhere.
There it is!
In this section. Next to the fallen tree.
[Anna] With Jeff Wilbusch... a crazy thing happened,
translation.ko: 제프 빌부슈를 얘기하자면 정말 말도 안 됐죠

translation.en: which is, our German casting director said,
"We have a German actor who speaks Yiddish."
translation.ko: '이디시어를 할 줄 아는 독일인 배우가 있어요'

translation.en: It was the end of the day. Alexa and I were sitting in the office.
translation.ko: 하루가 끝나갈 무렵 알렉사와 제가 지쳐서 여기 사무실에 앉아 있는데

translation.en: So this guy comes in, and we're, like, "This is what the show is about."
translation.ko: 이 사람이 들어오길래 작품 내용을 설명해 줬더니

translation.en: And he was, like, "This is my story." And we were, like, "I'm sorry?"
He's, like, "I am from the Satmar community in Mea She'arim.
"Yiddish is my native language. This is my story."
translation.ko: '이디시어는 제 모국어죠 제 얘기 같아요' 하더군요

translation.en: [Jeff] I think Moishe is a tragic role.
He is...
He has a lot of issues -
personal issues that he needs to fight.
He's haunted.
And he's also a hunter, so he comes... to bring Esther back.
Say it. Where is Esty?
Where is Esty, telephone?
You're crazy, Yanky.
[Anna] For us, the challenges of creating this Satmar wedding here, in Berlin,
translation.ko: 베를린에서 사트마 결혼식을 촬영하면서 겪은 첫 난관은

translation.en: began with finding enough extras who had big enough beards
and were willing to get all the hair and make-up.
I mean, you know, the joke on this show
translation.ko: 촬영장 내 농담 중 여자보다 남자한테

translation.en: is that the men required way more makeup than the women.
translation.ko: 헤어랑 메이크업이 더 필요하다는 게 있었죠

translation.en: Mine has grown now, almost one centimeter, because I wasn't allowed to cut it.
translation.ko: 자르면 안 된다고 해서 전 1cm쯤 기른 것 같아요

translation.en: It's a very complex, cultural ritual.
We wanted to get it right. A lot of details.
I'm just placing everybody in, sort of, gender and age order,
translation.ko: 성별과 나이 순서대로 사람들을 배치하고 있어요

translation.en: as well as imaginary relation to the bride and groom.
So there's a system to it.
[Anna] It's an incredible pageant,
a moment of great joy for the family,
but they don't express their joy
the way other communities express it.
I paid for everything, so, really, everything has to work out.
translation.ko: 제가 돈을 다 냈으니 모두 다 잘 풀려야 해요

translation.en: I check everyone - everyone's behavior.
And I'm having fun, but not too much.
translation.ko: 또 전 즐겁지만 너무 즐겁진 않답니다

translation.en: [Anna] It was very important to strike the right tone
translation.ko: 결혼식의 적당한 느낌을 내는 게 아주 중요했어요

translation.en: and then, also, we had, you know, 100 extras, costumes...
Well, the first challenge and the biggest challenge
was to shoot it all within these two days.
translation.ko: 이틀 안에 모든 촬영을 마쳐야 한다는 점이었죠

translation.en: [Anna] For us, it was our big Hollywood moment, you know,
and it was very hot when we were shooting.
Unfortunately, for all of the extras and actors,
they were wearing a lot of costume and make-up and hair
translation.ko: 의상을 두껍게 입고 헤어, 메이크업을 했는데

translation.en: in 100-degree weather.
Every day on set, it's, like, normal. Very, very normal.
translation.ko: 세트장은 늘 이래요 이 정도는 기본이죠

translation.en: That's what I'm used to, like, yes, all the time.

translation.ko: 개당 1천 유로가 넘어서 살 수가 없었어요

So, for Berlin, we really wanted to create

We, kind of, returned to a lot of former West Berlin,
translation.ko: 구 서베를린으로 돌아갔다고 할 수 있죠

translation.en: kind of, little locations and areas
and certain types of architectures that were built in the '70s and '80s.
I wanted to have something more with a freer space,
with more rhythm in it.
[Alexa] Silke found the most incredible location at Potsdamer Platz,
translation.ko: 베를린 필 바로 옆의 포츠다머 플라츠에서

translation.en: right next to the Philharmonic.
No one has ever shot there
and it was the perfect location for the music academy.
It was built in the '60s.
It was supposed to be a much lighter,
open architecture, post-war...
It was about communication.
It was about low hierarchy...
mirrored by architecture.
[Anna] We created our own music academy,
where Jews and Muslims are playing music together
translation.ko: 유대인과 이슬람교도가 함께 곡을 연주하게 했어요

translation.en: and, you know, it's also this crazy, post-colonial paradox.
translation.ko: 식민지 시대 후의 말도 안 되는 역설이죠

translation.en: Like, why are people from the Middle East playing German music at all?
translation.ko: '중동에서 온 사람들이 왜 독일 곡을 연주할까?'

translation.en: So, it has this, kind of, crazy, bringing together, of unexpected worlds,
translation.ko: 이 점이 의외의 세계들을 한데 모으는 역할을 해서

translation.en: that gets to the spirit of the show on every level.
translation.ko: 모든 것이 이 작품의 정신을 표현해 내요

translation.en: The concept of this music academy

translation.ko: 전 세계에서 온 다양하고 유능한 음악가들이

translation.ko: 자신의 악기를 갖고 연습하러 모인다는 거예요

translation.en: [Anna] Television is aspirational and we liked the idea
translation.ko: TV는 포부를 품어요 저희는 베를린의 한 면을 보여주고 싶었어요

translation.en: of showing a, kind of, version of Berlin

translation.ko: 과거의 음악과 결합한 음악으로 가득한 곳이자

translation.ko: 나치가 유대인을 강제수용소에서 죽이자고 결정한 회의가

Of course, seeing her being confronted with our world,
translation.ko: 에스터가 우리 세계와 마주한 모습을 보면

translation.en: Shooting a series in Yiddish...
in Berlin,
which has ironically... become a, kind of, new diaspora,
in the sense that you have young Israeli Jews,
young American Jews coming back to Berlin...
This is a movement. This is not a story of one person.
translation.ko: 그저 한 사람의 이야기가 아닌 운동이에요

translation.en: It just fit.
It makes sense that this is the place where we would rediscover this language,
translation.ko: 종교 밖의 문맥에서 이디시어를 재발견하는 곳이

translation.en: outside of a religious context.
So, there will be, like, art in Yiddish,
like there is theatre in Yiddish,
but, like, the real...
A Netflix series in Yiddish is something amazing.
